revised_title: Orientation Dependence of Human Line-Length Judgements and Real-World Scene Statistics
tldr: This study investigates the relationship between the orientation dependence of human line-length judgments and the statistical structure of real-world scenes. The research found that the apparent length of a line varies with its orientation, with vertical lines appearing longer than horizontal lines. The linear density of zero-crossings in Laplacian-of-Gaussian filtered images also shows a similar variation with orientation. This close correspondence suggests that the human visual system's orientation dependence of length judgments is influenced by the environmental structure of real-world scenes.
